made started the body about a decade

it wasn't a decade of working 40 hours a
woman but I had to take a break for a

do you remember it was last year he said

question how long did the whole process

process took about a decade last
question did Eric work continuously for

he had to take a break because there was

once he learned that skill then he was
able to complete his work all right we
have three sentences on the board can we
find three examples of the simple past
sure we can
finished took had you'll remember that
to form the simple past we usually add
II D or D but in English there are many
irregular verbs so you need to remember
that for example take becomes took have
becomes had why do we use the simple
past well it's obvious to talk about
past actions and past events finished
actions and finished events often with
the simple past we can specify a
specific point in time at which the
action or event occurred for example I
finished it one year ago we can look at
the past in pinpoint a specific time
also we use the simple past to refer to
things that lasted for a specific period
of time for example this process it took
about a decade a specific period of time
in the past this is a finished period of
time a closed period of time so the
simple past is finished and it's all in
the past there is no connection to the
present there is no connection to the
future if for example we made a
statement using the present perfect I've
finished then we could not use the
phrase one year ago because that is a
the time I've finished it you're simply
announcing that you're done but as soon
as you say a specific time you cannot
use the present perfect you can only use
the simple past
remember we use the simple past to
express finished actions or events that
happened in the past often we can name a
specific point in time for example
yesterday last week a year ago in 2002
these actions or events could happen in
isolation or they could happen in a
series of actions or series of events we
can also use this simple past to refer
to past events or states that lasted for
a specific period of time for example in
the 1970s or in my youth the simple past
is sometimes confused with the present
perfect but remember these two points
the present perfect refers to actions or
events that happened in the past but at
no specific time it's a general past
in contrast the simple past is more
specific also the present perfect can
refer to past actions or events which
have an effect on the present or which
may happen again in the future the
simple past has no such connections to
other time periods
in terms of form remember that the
simple past uses the endings II D or D
so talk becomes talked live becomes
lived if a verb ends in a silent e
simply add the D in terms of
pronunciation a voiceless consonant at
the end will make the e d ending sound
like a T talked a voiced consonant like
an Liv will make the e d ending sound
like a D lived also if a verb ends in a
T or D that edie ending will add an
extra syllable for example start it
landed if a verb ends with Y change the
Y to an i then add Edie try tried
however if there's a vowel before the Y
simply add Edie as in played in a verb
like stop you have a consonant vowel
consonant ending so double that final
consonant before you add ad stopped look
at visit there's also a consonant vowel
consonant ending however we have more
than one syllable
so we only need to double that final
consonant if that last syllable is
stressed in visit it's the first
syllable
that's stressed that's why we did not
need to double the T visited I know it's
a lot to remember on top of the spelling
rules you also have to remember a lot of
irregular verbs a lot of them however
you probably already know for example
the past forms of B or wasn't were C
become saw go becomes went and think
becomes thought I'll give you some more
practice in a moment with other
irregular verbs
also remember that the negative form and
short answers in the simple past require
an auxilary verb did we use did not or
the contraction didn't plus the base
verb to form the negative as in I didn't
play yesterday he didn't finish it in
short answers to yes/no questions you
can simply use that auxiliary verb for
example did you download the album yes I
did
no I didn't
let's do some practice in the simple
past in this exercise
